comment._content: Georges St., Limerick now known as O'Connell St

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Cruise's Royal Hotel had an advert in Freeman's July 27 1891, saying it had "A Commercial Room exclusively for Commercial Gentlemen" and "A Ladies' Coffee Room"

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I'm thinking a bit earlier than 1900: no motorcars, no bicycles, no straw boaters...

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
Advert in Freeman's February 18, 1885. Word of the day: "superintendence"
CRUISE'S ROYAL HOTEL, LIMERICK This old-established and well-known Hotel is now under the sole superintendence of the proprietor,and affords every accommodation to commercial gentlemen and tourists. The whole internal arrangements have been remodelled. The sanitary arrangements have been carefully looked after under the superintendence of an eminent engineer. Hot, cold, and shower baths. Omnibus meets all trains and steamers. JAMES FLYNN, Proprietor

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: You wouldn't expect cars in 1900 but the lack of bicycles is surprising.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Two Edward Bakers in 1901: Seedsmen. Still there in 1911.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: I assume this is Cruise's Royal Hotel in the 1901 census www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1901/Limerick/Limeri... James Flynn, hotel proprietor, is Head of family, and there are 3 waiters, 2 barmaids, 2 housemaids, a still room maid, a clerk, a boots, a bus driver and 4 visitors. One of the visitors, Henry James Bustard, is a "Surveyor of Gases"

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: maps.google.ie/maps?q=O'Connell+Street,+Limerick&hl=e... Not much left in the street view today.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: And James and Alice Flynn are still there in 1911

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Van Eesbeck, Hat Manufrs, gone by 1911.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Probably calls for an untimely death klaxon: In the 1911 census, it says that James and Alice Flynn had 13 children, of which only 7 were still living.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: There is a death notice for one Francois Van Eesbeck in this pdf.: Feb 6th, (1870) at 11 George's Street, of congestion of the lungs, Francois Van Eesbeck, a native of Lisle in France, in the 57th year of his age. Francis in 1900 was born in Cork, presumably Francois's's son?

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: The NLI have another, L_ROY_05286, taken from same spot where Cruise's Hotel has a "established date" on the façade. Can anyone make it out? There are also no cars or bicycles( there is one) so assume taken around same time. The telegraph/telephone had also come to town by the time L_ROY_05286 was taken.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Here we see a quote from a death notice for Van Eesbeck Sarah Josephine Avondale, Corbally 25/03/1899 wife of Francis Van Eesbeck Here is Avondale, Corbally. In 1911, we can see that Francis has remarried, and is living in Corbally still, a farmer and retired draper. Searching the Limerick Leader, I see a sale of "Sarahville", Corbally, on the instructions of Francis Sarsfield van Eesbeck, deceased, in July 1940. I wonder when he renamed the house "Sarahville", and what his new wife, Delia, thought of the name?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Any relation to rugby journo Ed Van Esbeck, I wonder?

comment.author: 30369211@N00

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] Checked the Super Dooper Hi Res of L_ROY_05286 and it shows Cruise's Hotel Established 1791. That image also shows the Cruise's Carriage outide the hotel. Different horses - the one on the right is a white or a grey. Plenty of cyclists, and people in straw boaters...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Sometimes you amaze me at the things you do not know!  you should read  - Jane and the Stillroom Maid (Jane Austen Mysteries #5) by Stephanie Barron. (Anyone over 16 years of age who wishes to use NLI collections may apply for a readers’ ticket)

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] (excluded from the above comments)
The still-room maid is a female servant who works in the still room, the functional room in a great house in which drinks and jams are made. The still-room maid is a junior servant, and as a member of the between staff, reports to both the housekeeper and the cook.

Once common in houses with large staffs, the still-room maid is rare in the 21st century.http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Still_room_maid

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] It sounds as if the electrification was a slow process, may have started in 1902 but when was George's Street/O'Connell Street done is the question...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

Hasselbeck's Ireland' pg.155. Also another photo can be seen here, halfway down the page - www.archiseek.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=46&t=3946&...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The George's Street, Limerick limerick If you feel like a great gorgeous treat Then stroll up and down George's Street. This fine thoroughfare Is good for fresh air Except for the poo - mind your feet!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Talking about droppings, this often occurs to me when looking at these old photos - did city councils in C19th Ireland employ anyone to clear up after the horses?  Contemporary Sydney photos show bag contraptions behind the horses, and they paid young 'blockboys' or 'sparrow-starvers' to pick up and resell the manure.  Apologies for lowering the tone (again), but I imagine it must have been a huge problem, and stench.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: I'd like to change the date range for this one on our catalogue from 1865-1914. Any educated guesstimates based on all of the above (electrification, businesses, etc.) for a better date range, please? I know we're around 1900 somewhere-ish...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Aha!. The Limerick City Trades Register says #9 was Michael Carr in 1877 and 1880, John Carr and Son Grocer/Tobacconist from 1877 to 1886, and then Thomas Hassett Ironmongers from 1891 to 1915. So, new latest date, 1891, earliest, 1877.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: #10 has a range of tenants. In the photo, you can make out a hotel (door at left) and a shop. The Clare Hotel belonged to the Misses O'Brien, Catherine and Julia, from 1856 to 1884. No sign of a hotel at that address after 1884. That suggests a latest date of 1886 (the first directory without the Clare Hotel at #10).

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: So, 1877 (Carr) to 1886 (Clare Hotel) ?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Hmm, earliest entry for Edward Baker is 1886, so I'll plump for 1886ish. The shop beneath the hotel should be Alexander Brothers grocers at that date, but I can't make anything out.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Thanks a million, Niall! So, circa 1877 to 1886...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
